title: Jeremiah Chapter 19 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Jeremiah chapter 19 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Jeremiah Chapter 19 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Jeremiah Chapter 19.

questions.question: What did the LORD command Jeremiah to get in Jeremiah 19:1?
questions.correctAnswer: A potter's earthen bottle
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 19:1 states that the LORD commanded Jeremiah to get a potter's earthen bottle.

questions.question: Where was Jeremiah told to go to proclaim the LORD's words according to Jeremiah 19:2?
options: The valley of the son of Hinnom
questions.correctAnswer: The valley of the son of Hinnom
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 19:2 instructs Jeremiah to go to the valley of the son of Hinnom to proclaim the LORD's words.

questions.question: Who did the LORD address in Jeremiah 19:3?
options: Kings of Judah and inhabitants of Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: Kings of Judah and inhabitants of Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 19:3 shows that the LORD's word was addressed to the kings of Judah and inhabitants of Jerusalem.

questions.question: What reason does the LORD give in Jeremiah 19:4 for bringing evil upon the place?
options: They have forsaken the LORD and burned incense to other gods
questions.correctAnswer: They have forsaken the LORD and burned incense to other gods
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 19:4 explains that the people forsook the LORD and burned incense to other gods, which caused God to bring evil upon the place.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 19:5, what did the people build to burn their sons as offerings?
questions.correctAnswer: High places of Baal
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 19:5 states that the people built high places of Baal to burn their sons as burnt offerings.

questions.question: What new name will the valley of the son of Hinnom be called as per Jeremiah 19:6?
questions.correctAnswer: The valley of slaughter
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 19:6 declares that the valley of the son of Hinnom will be called The valley of slaughter.

questions.question: What will happen to the people of Judah and Jerusalem according to Jeremiah 19:7?
options: They will fall by the sword before their enemies
They will be taken into exile peacefully
questions.correctAnswer: They will fall by the sword before their enemies
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 19:7 says the people will fall by the sword before their enemies as part of God's judgment.

questions.question: What will people do when passing by the city after the LORD’s judgment, according to Jeremiah 19:8?
options: They will be astonished and hiss
questions.correctAnswer: They will be astonished and hiss
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 19:8 states that every passerby will be astonished and hiss because of the city’s plagues.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 19:9, what horrific act will people be forced to do during the siege?
options: Eat the flesh of their sons and daughters
questions.correctAnswer: Eat the flesh of their sons and daughters
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 19:9 describes that people will eat the flesh of their own children due to the siege and distress.

questions.question: What symbolic action does Jeremiah perform in front of the men with him in Jeremiah 19:10?
questions.correctAnswer: He breaks the potter's bottle
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 19:10 describes Jeremiah breaking the bottle as a symbol of the coming destruction.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 19:11 says the people and city will be broken like a potter's vessel that cannot be made whole again.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 19:11 explicitly states the city and people will be broken like a potter’s vessel that cannot be repaired.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 19:13 mentions that incense was burned to all the host of heaven on the roofs of houses in Jerusalem.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 19:13 confirms incense was burned on the roofs to the host of heaven, defiling the houses.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 19:14 shows Jeremiah standing in the court of the LORD's house after coming from Tophet.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 19:14 states Jeremiah came from Tophet and stood in the LORD’s house court to speak.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Jeremiah 19:15: 'Behold, I will bring upon this city and upon all her towns all the ______ that I have pronounced against it.'
questions.correctAnswer: evil
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 19:15 states that God will bring all the evil He has pronounced upon the city and towns.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 19:12, what will God make this city like?
questions.correctAnswer: Tophet
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 19:12 says God will make the city like Tophet, a place of judgment and destruction.

medium.title: Jeremiah Chapter 19 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Jeremiah Chapter 19 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is discouraged by the consequences of disobedience. Based on Jeremiah 19:3-7, what biblical truth would you share about God's justice and warning?
options: God warns that disobedience leads to destruction and judgment.
God ignores the sins of His people and delays judgment.
God rewards disobedience with prosperity and peace.
God only punishes the kings, not the people.
questions.correctAnswer: God warns that disobedience leads to destruction and judgment.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 19:3-7 explains that God will bring evil upon the place due to forsaking Him and idolatry, resulting in judgment by sword and desolation. This teaches the seriousness of disobedience and God's justice.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 19:4-5 teach us about the importance of faithfulness in worship and family life?
options: Idolatry and sacrificing children are forbidden and provoke God's anger.
It is acceptable to worship other gods if it helps the family prosper.
Sacrificing children is commanded by God for blessing.
Faithfulness in worship has no impact on family life.
questions.correctAnswer: Idolatry and sacrificing children are forbidden and provoke God's anger.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 19:4-5 condemns burning incense to other gods and offering children as burnt offerings, highlighting that such acts are not commanded by God but provoke His judgment. This stresses the need for faithful worship and protecting family.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 19:9, the passage describes extreme suffering during siege. How can this teach believers about perseverance and trusting God in trials?
options: God allows trials but ultimately calls His people to trust and repent.
Trials are a sign God has abandoned believers completely.
Believers should avoid all difficulties at any cost.
Perseverance is unnecessary because God prevents all suffering.
questions.correctAnswer: God allows trials but ultimately calls His people to trust and repent.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 19:9 shows the dire consequences of sin and siege, yet the broader message in Jeremiah calls for repentance and trust in God's mercy despite trials (19:3-7, 19:15). This teaches perseverance with faith.

questions.question: What does the breaking of the potter’s vessel in Jeremiah 19:10-11 symbolize about God's judgment and the finality of consequences for rebellion?
options: God's judgment is irreversible and complete, like a broken vessel.
God's judgment is temporary and can be reversed anytime.
The potter’s vessel represents mercy and restoration.
questions.correctAnswer: God's judgment is irreversible and complete, like a broken vessel.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 19:10-11 uses the imagery of a broken potter’s vessel that cannot be repaired to symbolize the irrevocable destruction of the people due to their rebellion, teaching the seriousness of sin and consequences.

questions.question: A believer struggles with prayer and obedience. Based on Jeremiah 19:14-15, what encouragement can be given about God's faithfulness to His word despite human stubbornness?
options: God will bring the evil He has pronounced because people harden their necks and refuse to listen.
God ignores human disobedience and changes His mind often.
God’s word is conditional on human success only.
questions.correctAnswer: God will bring the evil He has pronounced because people harden their necks and refuse to listen.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 19:14-15 confirms God's faithfulness to His words, bringing judgment because the people hardened their necks and would not hear, teaching the importance of obedience and repentance.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 19 teaches that unrepentant sin leads to both individual and communal consequences.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The chapter repeatedly shows that the sins of the people affect the entire city and nation, resulting in collective judgment (19:7, 19:12, 19:15), teaching the impact of sin on community life.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 19:13 illustrate the importance of holiness in everyday life and family worship?
options: Burning incense to other gods on roofs defiles homes and families.
Worship practices have no effect on family holiness.
It is acceptable to mix worship of God with other gods.
Public worship alone is sufficient for family holiness.
questions.correctAnswer: Burning incense to other gods on roofs defiles homes and families.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 19:13 states that the houses and those of kings will be defiled because of incense burned to other gods on roofs, teaching that holiness must permeate the household and worship be exclusive to God.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with integrity at work. Based on the warnings in Jeremiah 19 about consequences of sin, what biblical principle can encourage honesty and faithfulness?
options: Sin leads to destruction; therefore, integrity and obedience honor God and preserve blessing.
Dishonesty is acceptable if it benefits you.
Integrity is unnecessary as God overlooks work behavior.
Only religious acts matter, not daily work ethics.
questions.correctAnswer: Sin leads to destruction; therefore, integrity and obedience honor God and preserve blessing.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 19 shows that sin, including idolatry and disobedience, brings destruction (19:3-7, 19:15), teaching that living with integrity and obedience in all areas, including work, honors God and prevents downfall.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 19 shows that God's judgment includes natural consequences, but also calls for repentance and trust in His mercy.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: While Jeremiah 19 describes harsh judgments (19:7-9), it occurs within a prophetic call to recognize sin and repent, implying God’s mercy is available to those who turn back (19:15).

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 19:1-2, what role does obedience to God's specific instructions play in being a faithful witness?
options: Obedience to God's commands is essential to effectively delivering His message.
Ignoring God's instructions is acceptable if intentions are good.
Faithfulness does not require specific obedience, only good intentions.
Proclaiming God’s word without obedience is equally effective.
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience to God's commands is essential to effectively delivering His message.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 19:1-2 shows God commanding Jeremiah to take a potter's bottle and go to a specific place to proclaim His words, illustrating that faithful witness requires obedience to God's directions.

questions.question: A believer is struggling to forgive others after they have sinned. Based on Jeremiah 19, what truth about consequences and restoration could help them?
options: God’s judgment is just but also calls for repentance and offers restoration.
Consequences are final, and forgiveness is not possible.
Forgiveness is unnecessary because punishment is enough.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s judgment is just but also calls for repentance and offers restoration.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 19 highlights God’s just judgment due to sin (19:7-9) but the overall biblical teaching encourages repentance and restoration, offering hope beyond consequences (19:15).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jeremiah 19 teaches that because the people ______ God and worshipped other gods, God would bring evil upon the place.
questions.correctAnswer: forsook
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 19:4 states the people forsook God and worshipped other gods, leading to God’s judgment, teaching the importance of faithfulness and obedience in devotion.

questions.question: How can the imagery of the "valley of slaughter" in Jeremiah 19:6 encourage believers in spiritual discipline and vigilance?
options: It warns that turning away from God leads to destruction and calls for vigilance in faith.
It suggests that judgment is always far away and not urgent.
It encourages carelessness since God will protect anyway.
It means physical valleys are dangerous but spiritual life is safe.
questions.correctAnswer: It warns that turning away from God leads to destruction and calls for vigilance in faith.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 19:6 renames the valley as "valley of slaughter" due to sin, symbolizing the consequences of turning from God and encouraging believers to remain disciplined and vigilant.

questions.question: What lesson about evangelism and warning others can be drawn from Jeremiah 19:3-4?
options: Proclaiming God’s word includes warning about consequences of sin to call people to repentance.
Evangelism should avoid mentioning sin or judgment.
Warnings are unnecessary if people are comfortable.
Only kings should be warned, not common people.
questions.correctAnswer: Proclaiming God’s word includes warning about consequences of sin to call people to repentance.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 19:3-4 shows Jeremiah commanded to proclaim the LORD’s words warning of evil due to sin, teaching that evangelism involves calling people to repentance with clear warnings.

questions.question: Based on Jeremiah 19:8, how can believers apply the teaching about community impact when sin remains unrepented?
options: Unrepented sin causes communal shame and desolation, urging believers to pursue holiness together.
Sin only affects individuals, not communities.
Communities are unaffected by individual actions.
Repentance is a private matter with no communal implications.
questions.correctAnswer: Unrepented sin causes communal shame and desolation, urging believers to pursue holiness together.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 19:8 shows the city becoming desolate and a byword due to sin, teaching that sin affects whole communities and believers must pursue collective holiness.

hard.title: Jeremiah Chapter 19 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Jeremiah Chapter 19.

questions.question: What object is Jeremiah commanded to take as a symbol in his prophetic act?
questions.correctAnswer: A potter's earthen bottle
questions.explanation: Jeremiah is instructed to take a potter's earthen bottle as a symbolic object to demonstrate God's judgment (Jeremiah 19:1).

questions.question: To which location is Jeremiah sent to deliver God's message?
options: Valley of the son of Hinnom
questions.correctAnswer: Valley of the son of Hinnom
questions.explanation: Jeremiah is sent to the valley of the son of Hinnom, near the east gate, to proclaim God's words (Jeremiah 19:2).

questions.question: What is the primary reason God pronounces judgment on Jerusalem in this chapter?
options: They have forsaken God and burned incense to other gods
They have allied with foreign nations
They have refused to pay taxes
questions.correctAnswer: They have forsaken God and burned incense to other gods
questions.explanation: The judgment is due to their forsaking God and offering incense to gods unknown to them and their ancestors (Jeremiah 19:4).

questions.question: What unnatural and detestable practice involving children is condemned in this chapter?
options: Burning sons with fire as offerings to Baal
Ignoring the sons and daughters in the community
Offering children at the temple altar
questions.correctAnswer: Burning sons with fire as offerings to Baal
questions.explanation: The chapter condemns the building of high places of Baal where sons were burned as offerings, a practice God did not command (Jeremiah 19:5).

questions.question: What new name will this place be called as a result of God's judgment?
questions.correctAnswer: The valley of slaughter
questions.explanation: God declares the place will be renamed from Tophet and the valley of the son of Hinnom to the valley of slaughter due to coming destruction (Jeremiah 19:6).

questions.question: What literary device is used when Jeremiah breaks the potter's bottle in front of the people?
questions.correctAnswer: Symbolic act of irreversible judgment
questions.explanation: Breaking the earthen bottle symbolizes how God will break the people and city beyond repair (Jeremiah 19:10-11).

questions.question: What is the fate of the inhabitants as described by the imagery of eating flesh in the siege?
options: They will resort to cannibalism due to extreme famine
They will offer sacrifices to God
They will fast and pray for deliverance
questions.correctAnswer: They will resort to cannibalism due to extreme famine
questions.explanation: The text grimly foretells that in the siege, people will eat the flesh of their own children and friends out of desperation (Jeremiah 19:9).

questions.question: How does the chapter foreshadow the total destruction that will come upon Jerusalem and Judah?
options: By comparing the city to a shattered pot that cannot be repaired
By blessing the city with future restoration
questions.correctAnswer: By comparing the city to a shattered pot that cannot be repaired
questions.explanation: The breaking of the potter's vessel illustrates the irrevocable destruction awaiting the city and people (Jeremiah 19:11).

questions.question: What cultural-religious practice involving the 'host of heaven' is condemned in this chapter?
options: Burning incense and pouring out drink offerings on the roofs
questions.correctAnswer: Burning incense and pouring out drink offerings on the roofs
questions.explanation: The inhabitants burned incense and poured drink offerings to the host of heaven on the roofs, which defiled the houses (Jeremiah 19:13).

questions.question: The 'valley of the son of Hinnom' is historically connected to which of the following themes in biblical literature?
options: A place of idolatry and child sacrifice
The location of the first temple
questions.correctAnswer: A place of idolatry and child sacrifice
questions.explanation: The valley of the son of Hinnom was associated with idolatrous practices and child sacrifice, as reflected in Jeremiah's prophecy (Jeremiah 19:2, 19:5).

questions.question: Which Old Testament book contains a similar prophetic imagery of breaking a vessel as a symbol of judgment?
questions.correctAnswer: Nahum
questions.explanation: Nahum 2:10 uses the imagery of breaking a vessel to symbolize the destruction of Nineveh, similar to Jeremiah's broken bottle (Jeremiah 19:10-11).

questions.question: True or False: The chapter indicates that the kings of Judah were involved in the idolatrous practices condemned by Jeremiah.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah states that neither the kings of Judah nor their ancestors knew the gods they burned incense to, implicating them in the idolatry (Jeremiah 19:4).

questions.question: What is the ultimate purpose of Jeremiah's prophecy in the LORD's house courtyard after returning from Tophet?
options: To warn the people of the coming evil due to their hardened hearts
To announce the rebuilding of the city
To call the people to a festival
questions.correctAnswer: To warn the people of the coming evil due to their hardened hearts
questions.explanation: Jeremiah proclaims God's judgment because the people have hardened their necks and refused to hear His words (Jeremiah 19:14-15).

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 19 develop the theme of covenant unfaithfulness seen throughout the book of Jeremiah?
options: By illustrating the consequences of idolatry and child sacrifice as covenant breaches
By emphasizing the rebuilding of the temple
questions.correctAnswer: By illustrating the consequences of idolatry and child sacrifice as covenant breaches
questions.explanation: The chapter portrays the people's idolatry and sacrifice of children as violations of the covenant, resulting in severe judgment (Jeremiah 19:4-5).

questions.question: Which New Testament passage echoes the imagery of the valley of the son of Hinnom as a place of judgment and fire?
questions.correctAnswer: Matthew 5:22
questions.explanation: Matthew 5:22 references 'Gehenna,' related to the valley of the son of Hinnom, as a place of fiery judgment, connecting to Jeremiah's prophecy (Jeremiah 19:6).

theological.title: Jeremiah Chapter 19 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Jeremiah Chapter 19 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What symbolic object did the LORD instruct Jeremiah to take in Jeremiah 19:1 to demonstrate His judgment?
questions.correctAnswer: A potter's earthen bottle
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 19:1 states that the LORD commanded Jeremiah to take a potter's earthen bottle, symbolizing the fragility and breakability of Judah, consistent with the potter metaphor in Isaiah 64:8 and Romans 9:21.

questions.question: Where did God command Jeremiah to go and proclaim His word in Jeremiah 19:2?
options: The valley of the son of Hinnom
questions.correctAnswer: The valley of the son of Hinnom
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 19:2 directs Jeremiah to the valley of the son of Hinnom, a place associated with idolatry and judgment, foreshadowing the ultimate destruction referenced in Matthew 5:22 and Revelation 21:8.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 19:3, who is addressed to hear the word of the LORD?
options: Kings of Judah and inhabitants of Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: Kings of Judah and inhabitants of Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 19:3 explicitly addresses the kings of Judah and inhabitants of Jerusalem, emphasizing God's judgment on leadership and people, paralleling warnings to leaders in Ezekiel 22:30 and Acts 7:51.

questions.question: What is the primary reason for God's judgment in Jeremiah 19:4?
options: Forsaking God and burning incense to other gods
questions.correctAnswer: Forsaking God and burning incense to other gods
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 19:4 shows that the people forsook God and worshiped false gods, which is a root cause of judgment, consistent with Deuteronomy 6:14-15 and 1 Kings 18:21.

questions.question: What horrific practice involving children is condemned in Jeremiah 19:5?
options: Burning their sons with fire for Baal
questions.correctAnswer: Burning their sons with fire for Baal
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 19:5 condemns child sacrifice to Baal, a practice God never commanded, paralleling condemnations in Leviticus 18:21 and 2 Kings 23:10.

questions.question: What new name does God say the valley of the son of Hinnom will be called according to Jeremiah 19:6?
questions.correctAnswer: The valley of slaughter
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 19:6 declares that the valley will be called 'The valley of slaughter,' signifying coming judgment, echoing themes of destruction in Joel 3:14 and Revelation 14:20.

questions.question: How does God describe His judgment on Judah and Jerusalem in Jeremiah 19:7?
options: They will fall by the sword and their carcasses will be food for birds and beasts
They will be spared for repentance
They will be delivered by a prophet
questions.correctAnswer: They will fall by the sword and their carcasses will be food for birds and beasts
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 19:7 foretells violent judgment including death and desecration, consistent with descriptions of divine judgment in Ezekiel 39:4 and Luke 17:37.

questions.question: What extreme measure of desperation does God say will occur during the siege in Jeremiah 19:9?
options: Eating the flesh of their sons, daughters, and friends
questions.correctAnswer: Eating the flesh of their sons, daughters, and friends
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 19:9 describes cannibalism during siege as a judgment symbolizing utter devastation, paralleling 2 Kings 6:28-29 and Lamentations 4:10.

questions.question: What action is Jeremiah commanded to perform with the potter's bottle in Jeremiah 19:10?
options: Break it in sight of the men
questions.correctAnswer: Break it in sight of the men
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 19:10 instructs Jeremiah to break the bottle publicly, symbolizing the irreversible destruction of the people, similar to symbolic acts in Ezekiel 12:3 and Isaiah 30:14.

questions.question: What does the breaking of the potter's vessel symbolize in Jeremiah 19:11?
options: The breaking of the people and city beyond repair
questions.correctAnswer: The breaking of the people and city beyond repair
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 19:11 explains the broken vessel represents the destruction of Jerusalem and Judah, a metaphor of God's sovereign judgment, paralleled in Psalm 2:9 and Isaiah 30:14.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 19:13, why will the houses of Jerusalem and kings be defiled like Tophet?
options: Because incense and drink offerings were made to the host of heaven and other gods
Because they failed to build the temple
Because they made alliances with Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: Because incense and drink offerings were made to the host of heaven and other gods
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 19:13 condemns idolatrous worship practices on rooftops, reflecting apostasy condemned in 2 Kings 21:3-5 and Deuteronomy 12:2-3.

questions.question: What message did Jeremiah proclaim in the court of the LORD's house after coming from Tophet as in Jeremiah 19:14-15?
options: God will bring all the evil pronounced upon Jerusalem because they hardened their necks
God will restore Jerusalem after repentance
God will send a Messiah immediately
God will forgive their sins without judgment
questions.correctAnswer: God will bring all the evil pronounced upon Jerusalem because they hardened their necks
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 19:15 emphasizes the certainty of judgment due to obstinate rebellion, consistent with warnings in Hebrews 3:13 and Proverbs 29:1.

questions.question: What does the valley of the son of Hinnom symbolize in biblical theology as seen in Jeremiah 19?
options: A place of judgment and defilement
A place of blessing and covenant
A site for gathering the tribes
questions.correctAnswer: A place of judgment and defilement
questions.explanation: The valley symbolizes judgment and defilement due to idolatry and child sacrifice (Jeremiah 19:2-6), paralleling its later association with Gehenna in Matthew 5:22 and Mark 9:43.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 19 reflect the attribute of God's justice?
options: Through pronouncing judgment for idolatry and injustice
By ignoring the sins of the people
questions.correctAnswer: Through pronouncing judgment for idolatry and injustice
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 19 depicts God's justice in punishing sin and idolatry (Jeremiah 19:4-9, 14-15), consistent with Psalm 9:7-8 and Romans 2:5-6.

questions.question: What theological lesson about human sin and divine judgment can be drawn from the breaking of the potter's vessel in Jeremiah 19?
options: Human sin leads to irreversible divine judgment
Judgment can be avoided by rituals
questions.correctAnswer: Human sin leads to irreversible divine judgment
questions.explanation: The broken vessel in Jeremiah 19:10-11 symbolizes the irreversible consequences of sin, teaching divine holiness and justice, consistent with Romans 6:23 and Hebrews 10:26-27.
